The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
The same organisers of the "Day of Anger" and "Friday of Anger" called for a protest which was dubbed the "'''Friday of Departure'''". In Cairo, they planned to march to [[Heliopolis Palace]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163162.html|title=4 Feb. Declared the 'Friday of Departure'|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Press TV]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|gumÊ¿at ar-raá¸¥Ä«l}}'')<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alraimedia.com/Alrai/Article.aspx?id=253982&date=02022011|title=Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ±Ø­ÙÙ|language=[[Arabic language|Arabic]]|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Al Rai]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> They demanded Mubarak step down immediately, with 4 February their deadline for him to surrender his powers.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Protests-What-Will-Be-The-Future-For-President-Mubarak/Article/201102115920698?lpos=World_News_First_World_News_Article_Teaser_Region_4&lid=ARTICLE_15920698_Egypt_Protests%3A_What_Will_Be_The_Future_For_President_Mubarak|title=What Is the Future for President Mubarak?|author=|date=2 February 2011|work=[[Sky News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
â
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as many of the protesters again spent the night in Tahrir Square. Pro-government protesters were also active and small-scale clashes happened in the early hours.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
During the night of 3â4 February, there were tanks on the street in Cairo as many of the protesters again spent the night in Tahrir Square. Pro-government protesters were also active and small-scale clashes happened in the early hours.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/03/live-blog-feb-4-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 4 – Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
[[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|A tank situated on the entrance to Tahrir Square.]]
[[File:Abrams in Tahrir.jpg|thumb|left|A tank situated on the entrance to Tahrir Square.]]
â
Two million Egyptians flooded Tahrir Square to participate in Friday day prayer in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=235172|title=2 million Egyptians turn out for Day of Departure|publisher=[[Tehran Times]]|date=2011-02-05|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> [[Egyptian Christians]] and others not performing Friday prayers formed a "human chain" around those praying to protect them from any potential disruptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/02/the-day-of-departure-its-either-death-or-freedom.html|author=Chris Bodenner|title="The Day Of Departure": Calm But Determined|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=}}</ref> The day's planned events began after Friday prayers. Al Jazeera estimated the crowd size to be over a million in Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://www.demotix.com/news/579902/flags-egypt-raised-above-tahrir-square "Flags of Egypt raised above Tahrir Square"] ''Demotix - News By You'' - Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei was also in attendance. Protesters held portraits of former presidents [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] and [[Anwar Sadat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/05/stories/2011020565420100.htm |title=Front Page : Ball in Mubarak's court as democracy pressure mounts |publisher=The Hindu |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> However, protesters did not get to the presidential palace. In Alexandria, over a million protesters turned out, making it the biggest ever protest in Alexandria. They warned that if the government used violence against protesters in Cairo, they would march to Cairo to join the protesters there.<ref name="aljazlive"/>
+
Two million Egyptians flooded Tahrir Square to participate in Friday day prayer in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=235172|title=2 million Egyptians turn out for Day of Departure|publisher=[[Tehran Times]]|date=2011-02-05|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> [[Egyptian Christians]] and others not performing Friday prayers formed a "human chain" around those praying to protect them from any potential disruptions.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/02/the-day-of-departure-its-either-death-or-freedom.html|author=Chris Bodenner|title="The Day Of Departure": Calm But Determined|publisher=The Atlantic|accessdate=}}</ref> The day's planned events began after Friday prayers. Al Jazeera estimated the crowd size to be over a million in Tahrir Square.<ref>[http://www.demotix.com/news/579902/flags-egypt-raised-above-tahrir-square "Flags of Egypt raised above Tahrir Square"] ''Demotix - News By You'' - Retrieved 4 February 2011.</ref> Mohammed ElBaradei was also in attendance. Protesters held portraits of former presidents [[Gamal Abdel Nasser]] and [[Anwar Sadat]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/05/stories/2011020565420100.htm |title=Front Page : Ball in Mubarak's court as democracy pressure mounts |publisher=The Hindu |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> However, protesters did not get to the presidential palace. In Alexandria, over a million protesters turned out, making it the biggest ever protest in Alexandria. They warned that if the government used violence against protesters in Cairo, they would march to Cairo to join the protesters there.<ref name="aljazbloglive4feb"/>
Protest marches were also held in Giza and [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201124175331299951.html |title=Egypt holds 'Day of Departure' - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Suez, [[Port Said]], [[Rafah, Egypt|Rafah]], [[IsmaÃ¯lia|Ismailiya]], [[Zagazig]], [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|al-Mahalla al-Kubra]], [[Aswan]] and [[Asyut]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12371479 Obama seeks quick Egypt handover], BBC News, 5 Feb 2011</ref>
Protest marches were also held in Giza and [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201124175331299951.html |title=Egypt holds 'Day of Departure' - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> Suez, [[Port Said]], [[Rafah, Egypt|Rafah]], [[IsmaÃ¯lia|Ismailiya]], [[Zagazig]], [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra|al-Mahalla al-Kubra]], [[Aswan]] and [[Asyut]].<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-12371479 Obama seeks quick Egypt handover], BBC News, 5 Feb 2011</ref>
